title: 106_hr4675
content: The "USDA Accountability and Equity Act of 2000" includes provisions for improved accountability of county and area committees and their employees, as well as measures for enhanced program equity. This Act outlines membership requirements, oversight of committee elections, and federal civil service status for committee employees. The "USDA Accountability and Equity Act of 2000" includes provisions for socially disadvantaged farmers and ranchers in environmental quality incentives program, grants for upgrading agricultural facilities at 1890 land-grant colleges, funding for outreach to disadvantaged farmers, extension Indian reservation program, and farm ownership and operating loan programs. Effective 90 days after enactment, the Soil Conservation and Domestic Allotment Act is amended to specify the composition and election procedures for county or area committees representing agricultural producers. The Secretary appoints committee members based on recommendations from under-represented groups, providing reasons if appointing someone not recommended. Improved oversight of county, area, and community committee elections is addressed in Section 102. The Secretary of Agriculture will establish uniform guidelines for elections of committee members and delegates. Amendments to the Soil Conservation and Domestic Allotment Act require certification of election results to ensure compliance with laws before members can begin their term. The Secretary will certify that the election followed all laws and guidelines, and that the members-elect meet committee membership requirements. SEC. 103. FEDERAL CIVIL SERVICE STATUS OF COUNTY AND AREA COMMITTEE EMPLOYEES. The term "county committee employee" refers to an employee of a county or area committee under the Soil Conservation and Domestic Allotment Act. Civil service laws now apply to all county committee employees, with conversion options for existing employees. Permanent county committee employees are converted to Federal civil service appointments after 3 years of service. A county committee employee with 3 years of service gets a career civil service appointment, while those with less than 3 years get a career-conditional appointment. Temporary employees are converted to temporary Federal civil service appointments. Service as a county committee employee before a certain date is credited. Before the effective date of this section, service as a county committee employee is credited as Federal service for various purposes. Former permanent county committee employees may receive special selection priority for civil service positions in the Farm Service Agency for 2 years after separation. Amendments are made to certain sections of the Department of Agriculture Reorganization Act of 1994 and Title 5 of the United States Code. Amendments are made to Title 5, United States Code, including striking specific sections related to the Soil Conservation and Domestic Allotment Act before the effective date of the USDA Accountability and Equity Act of 2000. The amendments include changes to section 8(b)(5)(E) of the Soil Conservation and Domestic Allotment Act, with the effective date set to 180 days after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 201. Participation of socially disadvantaged farmers and ranchers in Environmental Quality Incentives Program. Section 1201(a) of the Food Security Act of 1985 is amended to include a definition of "socially disadvantaged farmer or rancher" as a member of a socially disadvantaged group, with limited resources, or a member of a federally recognized Indian tribe. Section 1241(b) is also amended to increase funding availability. In paragraph (1), funding for fiscal years 1997 through 2002 is adjusted to $200,000,000 for 1997-2000 and $300,000,000 for 2001-2002. In paragraph (2), the percentage is changed from 50% to one-third. New paragraphs are added to allocate one-third of funding for socially disadvantaged farmers and ranchers in 2001 and 2002. In the Food Security Act of 1985, amendments prioritize assistance for socially disadvantaged farmers and ranchers. Funding through the environmental quality incentives program remains available until expended. Timing of payments and cost-share limitations are also addressed in the amendments. The amendments to the Food Security Act of 1985 prioritize assistance for socially disadvantaged farmers and ranchers by allowing the Secretary to waive cost-share requirements and adjust payment rates. Additionally, in-kind contributions such as labor, materials, or equipment can be counted towards the producer's share of the cost for structural practices. The amendments to the Food Security Act of 1985 prioritize assistance for socially disadvantaged farmers and ranchers by allowing the Secretary to waive cost-share requirements and adjust payment rates. In-kind contributions can be counted towards the producer's share of the cost for structural practices. The producer must be a socially disadvantaged farmer or rancher. SEC. 202. Grants to upgrade agricultural and food sciences facilities at 1890 land-grant colleges, including Tuskegee University. $15,000,000 appropriated annually for this purpose. SEC. 203. Funding of program of outreach and technical assistance to socially disadvantaged farmers. Section 2501(a)(3) of the Food, Agriculture, Conservation, and Trade Act of 1990 is amended to appropriate $10,000,000 annually for the Secretary. Section 1677(g) is also amended to allocate $8,000,000 annually for the Extension Indian Reservation Program. SEC. 205 of the Consolidated Farm and Rural Development Act allocates $585,000,000 annually for direct loans to the Secretary for farm ownership and operating loans. $85,000,000 is designated for farm ownership loans, and $500,000,000 for operating loans.
